document_data.name: Holy Book
document_data.mainbody:
=Temple Tomes===
In their most usual form, holy books were [[tome]]s containing a collection of prayers and rituals dedicated to a specific [[deity]]. Those prayers could be used to learn new [[divine magic|divine spells]], but that privilege was usually reserved those faithful to that deity. A typical holy book could teach around 10 to 20 spells.

[[File:Blackbook.jpg|thumb|left|120px|''The Black Book of Beshaba was four feet tall.'']]
The most common of holy books were called ''temple tomes'', because they were jealously guarded in holy [[temple]]s. Temple tomes were usually stored in highly protected vaults or hidden chambers, and some clergies went as far as displaying replicas on elevated reliquaries for their flocks to admire. Stored temple books were often guarded by magical guardians chosen amongst those whose natural powers would not damage the items.

Holy books were crafted with lots of care. Some were made of rare and expensive materials, such as the hide of exotic beasts, in order to impress the devout. Others were built with durability in mind, using methods such as stamping words on everbright metal pages.

Supplicants desiring to consult a temple tome were often required to jump through many hoops, such as performing difficult or humiliating tasks for the clergy, or paying a hefty fee. Accessing such a book was only possible for members of that clergy or for members of other churches that had at least a cordial relation with them, however many temples would sell scrolls of spells copied from those books—at a high price. Consulting a temple tome was always done under the strict supervision of guardian priests powerful enough to prevent the book being stolen or damaged. Unveiling of such books was a rare event, and as such was often accompanies with chanting, rituals and public drama, ruining any chance for anonymity.

document_data.Powers:
Typical holy books didn't magically affect individuals who simply read them or shifted their pages). It was however a common occurrence for those books to be protected by [[Glyph of warding|glyphs of warding]] unleashing magical defenses against creature of the wrong [[alignment]], race, or even temple rank. Such glyphs were carefully crafted by the churches with divine approval, and were hidden alongside various symbols, holy runes, and "dummy" glyphs designed to waste the spells and time of intruders.

Because of the divine permission granted by deities, holy books could be used by priests of the corresponding faith to learn spells outside the [[sphere]]s normally available to them.

[[File:Wythyndles-round-book.png|thumb|right|150px|''Wythyndle's Round Book surrounded by two Sorlyn priests.'']]
document_data.Content:
The exact content of holy books could vary slightly, but they were usually organized as follow:
* An opening prayer or invocation dedicated to a deity. It was purely for religious purposes and didn't teach any spell.
* A detailed ritual or offering to that deity.
* A new ritual, or a modification of an existing one. For example a ritual to remove vermin from a temple, or a fastest way to learn from the deity the name a lay person would take upon assuming priesthood.
* A collection of prayers teaching spells. They were ordered in ascending order of power, to ensure the novice's safety.
* A closing prayer praising the deity. As for the opening section, this had purely religious purpose and didn't teach any spell. This section sometimes contained drawings of approved holy symbols, designs, of glyphs.

Notable Holy Books.The Argyr: A magical cube made of [[adamantine]] and plated with [[electrum]], containing sacred spells of the [[Gond]]ar faith.
Notable Holy Books.Balance of Belaros: This holy book dedicated to [[Tyr]] was a set of magically floating [[bronze]] scales, which could be used to exchange offerings for [[scroll|spell scrolls]].
Notable Holy Books.The Black Book: This very tall book was dedicated to the goddess [[Beshaba]]. It was said to suck the vitality from its readers, and to have the ability to make [[undead]] creatures disappear altogether.
Notable Holy Books.Book of Fangs and Talons: A heavy book sacred to [[Malar]], made of heavy [[vellum]] pages bound between turtle shells and covered in beast furs.<ref>
Notable Holy Books.Chanting Chain:
This unusual holly book dedicated to [[Talos]] had the appearance of a massive steel chain, whose links were large enough for a child's head to pass through.
[[File:Balance.jpg|thumb|left|120px|''Some holy books took strange shapes, such as a magical floating set of scales.'']]
Notable Holy Books.Crystrum of Tranquility: This crystal sphere revealed spells to the followers of [[Eldath]] when immersed in running water.
Notable Holy Books.Flame of the Spirit: One of the most holy relics of the [[Tymora]]n faith, this amber gemstone shaped like flame would transform into a tablet revealing spells in the hands of the faithful.
Notable Holy Books.The Glarathra: A large bronze flower {{SI|3|feet|}} in length, this holy book was dedicated to the goddess [[Chauntea]].
Notable Holy Books.Gorothir's Girdle: This holy book dedicated to [[Shar]] was a black leather [[corset]] studded with many small figures carved out of [[jet]]. Its spells were accessed by inserting the proper [[gem]]s inside the figure's eye sockets.
Notable Holy Books.Helm of Helm: This heavy metallic [[Helmet|war-helm]] was dedicated to [[Helm|the eponymous deity]].
Notable Holy Books.Key of Faith: This holy book dedicated to [[Oghma]] had the form of a {{SI|2|feet|}} long ornate silver key.
Notable Holy Books.Lash of Loviatar: This leather [[whip]] was a divine relic of [[Loviatar]], and would only display a single spell at a given time. The displayed spell could be changed by striking the whip at a victim.
Notable Holy Books.Leaves of Green: This indestructible piece of bark would turn into a book when one of the many names of [[Silvanus]] was spoken aloud.
Notable Holy Books.Mask of Mysteries: This black [[silk]] mask concealed the features of the wearer and gave them a sinister appearance. It had the ability to reveal spells bestowed by [[Mask|the Lord of Shadows]].
Notable Holy Books.Mighty Rune of the Master: This holy book of [[Deneir]] was a magically floating, three-dimensional rune made of an unknown metal alloy. While floating it rotated slowly and chimed softly.
Notable Holy Books.Moonweb_(book)|Moonweb: This set of magical [[silver]] [[ring]]s could grant magical powers to the followers of [[Sel√ªne]], and could create intangible floating "pages" of glowing air if worn in the proper manner.
Notable Holy Books.Orglara: A {{SI|2|feet|}} large by {{SI|3|feet|}} long platter of iridescent abalone shell, which revealed spells granted by [[Umberlee]] when in contact with rolling sea water.
Notable Holy Books.Red Book of War: A massive holy book dedicated to [[Tempus]], whose covers were made of beaten armor plates.
Notable Holy Books.Sash of Sune: This scarlet [[sash]] about {{SI|5|feet}} long was a holy book of [[Sune]], and revealed its secrets to a priest of [[Church of Sune|her church]] dancing barefoot over it.
Notable Holy Books.Scepter of Mystra: This divine [[Mystran]] artifact was well-known from even the laypeople, as it appeared in numerous children tales.
Notable Holy Books.Silver Supplicant:
This holy book was a silver statuette representing a priestess of [[Auril]].
[[File:Testament of Vraer.png|thumb|right|120px|''The spine of the holy book of Kelemvor featured a carved human bone.'']]
Notable Holy Books.Testament of Vraer: This holy book dedicated to [[Kelemvor]] looked like an actual book, although a rather macabre one.
Notable Holy Books.Tome of Morning: This holy book of [[Lathander]] had covers made of [[quartz]] and gilded steel, and its front page was decorated with a lidless, moving [[blue dragon]] hatchling's eye.
Notable Holy Books.Tome of Torment: The most holy tome of the [[church of Ilmater]], it looked like a shirt made of [[horse]]hair with small barbed hooks on the inside. Unsurprisingly, followers of the [[Ilmater|Broken God]] had to suffer in order to unlock its teachings.
Notable Holy Books.Tome of Universal Harmony: The most holy book of the [[Deneirrath]] faith, whose spells could only be learnt by the deity's [[Chosen]].
Notable Holy Books.Veloghon of Vigilance: This tome dedicated to [[Torm]] had the appearance of a large, battle-weary [[shield|war-shield]].
Notable Holy Books.Vorthryn¬ís Archivir: This thin book of classic design, measuring about {{SI|2|feet|}} across by {{SI|4|feet|}} in height, was a ''touched tome'', a divine book of [[Azuth]]. When closed, it created sparkling motes of light around it.
Notable Holy Books.Wythyndle's Round Book: Bestowed by [[Milil]] himself to [[Church of Milil|its clergy]] during the 10{{th}} century [[DR]], this book contained several exclusive spells and had the ability to teleport itself around [[Faer√ªn]].
Notable Holy Books.Yornar's Trail Companion:
The cover of this crescent book dedicated to [[Mielikki]] was made of [[ironwood]].


In addition the following items were considered ''holy books'' despite not teaching any new spells to their readers, or despite not being dedicated to a specific deity:
[[File:Book_of_Exalted_Deeds_MtG.jpg|thumb|left|250px|''An angelic being holding the Book of Exalted Deeds.'']]
Notable Holy Books.Book of Exalted Deeds: An [[artifact]] of great power, this book wasn't dedicated to a single deity but was considered as the supreme written authority of [[good]]ness and virtue in all the [[multiverse]].
Notable Holy Books.Book of Perfect Balance: A holy book that wasn't dedicated to a single deity, but was considered sacred by creatures of [[neutral]] alignment. Once read this book disappeared, and the reader would never encounter it again.
Notable Holy Books.Testament of Jade: A relic of the [[Lathanderian]] faith, which granted its owner the ability to cast several divine spells on a daily basis.
Notable Holy Books.Tome of the Dragon: The holy book of the [[Cult of the Dragon]], whose members venerated [[dracolich]]es.
